channel.title: BBC News - Science & Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Hayabusa-2: Japanese spacecraft makes final touchdown on asteroid
item.description: The Hayabusa-2 craft will pick up fresh space rock that could help explain how the Solar System evolved.

item.title: A68: World's biggest iceberg is on the move
item.description: The giant block of ice has spun around and is now moving north along the Antarctic Peninsula.

item.title: Climate change: How hot cities could be in 2050
item.description: Edinburgh will feel like Paris and Leeds could be as warm as Melbourne, according to a study.

item.title: Earliest modern human found outside Africa
item.description: Researchers have found the earliest example of our species outside Africa.

item.title: European Vega rocket lost minutes after lift-off
item.description: The rocket carrying a satellite is believed to have landed in the sea, the first failure in 15 launches.

item.title: Stonehenge mini model reveals sound of monument
item.description: The model gives an insight "into what our ancestors would have heard", an academic says.

item.title: Suzanne Eaton, US scientist, found dead in WW2 bunker on Crete
item.description: Police on the Greek island say Suzanne Eaton, who was there for a conference, died of suffocation.

item.title: Russian nuclear submarine: Norway finds big radiation leak
item.description: Experts say there is no alarm, despite a high level of caesium at a Soviet-era submarine wreck.

item.title: Pollution warning over car tyre and brake dust
item.description: Even going electric won't stop cars polluting city streets, government advisers say.

item.title: Climate change: UK government 'like Dad's Army'
item.description: The UK's "ramshackle" approach means emissions are not being cut fast enough, advisers say,

item.title: Bloodhound supersonic car to run at high speed in October
item.description: The UK-led attempt to break the land speed record will conduct 500-600mph trials later this year.

item.title: Climate change: Water and green energy produced by a single device
item.description: Researchers adapt a solar panel so that it can produce drinking water from the sea as well as green electricity.

item.title: Attenborough: Climate risks Africa turmoil
item.description: The naturalist and broadcaster Sir David Attenborough says that climate change will make parts of Africa uninhabitable.

item.title: Jodrell Bank gains Unesco World Heritage status
item.description: The observatory, which tracked US and Russian craft during the space race, wins Unesco recognition.

item.title: California earthquake leaves scar on the desert
item.description: Satellite pictures shows how the 7.1 magnitude earthquake changed the landscape.

item.title: 'Amazing' gene-silencing drugs reach NHS
item.description: Doctors say the drugs are making the "previously untreatable, treatable" and have huge potential.

item.title: Badgers lead mammal roadkill list
item.description: More than 900 badgers have been reported dead by the side of UK roads so far this year.

item.title: Mystery 'tequila plant' agave to flower in Cambridge after 57 years
item.description: University gardeners are ready to remove a glasshouse roof after the plant had a sudden growth spurt.

item.title: 'Rewiring nerves' reverses hand and arm paralysis
item.description: "It's made a huge difference in my life," says one patient who can now live independently.

item.title: Trump praises his administration's environmental efforts
item.description: The US president did not mention climate change, but spoke of improvements to the economy and pollution.

item.title: Electric cars 'will not solve transport problem,' report warns
item.description: Car use will still need to be curbed, even when all vehicles use clean electricity, a report warns.

item.title: Obituary: Georges Brossard, the man who stuck up for insects
item.description: Georges Brossard devoted his life to helping us appreciate "the most misunderstood animals".

item.title: Mandla Maseko: Would-be African astronaut dies in road crash
item.description: Mandla Maseko, from South Africa, won a chance to become the first black African in space.

item.title: California earthquake: Power 'restored to most' after 7.1-magnitude quake
item.description: Power has been restored to most homes that lost it in the 7.1-magnitude earthquake.

item.title: LGBT+ scientists affected by discrimination
item.description: A report finds that 28% of LGBT+ people working in the physical sciences have considered leaving their jobs due to discrimination.

item.title: Alaska heatwave: Anchorage hits record temperature
item.description: Several places in southern Alaska are experiencing record temperatures, including its largest city.

item.title: Sargassum: The biggest seaweed bloom in the world
item.description: Known as the Great Atlantic Sargassum Belt, the seaweed stretches from West Africa to the Gulf of Mexico.

item.title: Toxic processionary caterpillar plague spreads across Europe
item.description: The wind-blown hairs of oak caterpillars are a health risk in Germany and Benelux countries.

item.title: Madrid low emission zone reinstated after protests
item.description: The new mayor had suspended fines for five days, during which there was a "surge" in pollution.

item.title: Apollo 11: 'The greatest single broadcast in television history'
item.description: The moon landing 50 years ago brought previously unthinkable images and ideas to millions.

item.title: Mumbai rains: Is India's weather becoming more extreme?
item.description: With Mumbai seeing its heaviest rain in a decade, Reality Check looks at India's extreme weather patterns.

item.title: Artificial lionfish powered by ‘robotic blood’
item.description: The circulatory system fitted to the synthetic fish allows it to be powered for about 40 hours.

item.title: Moon landings: What was the 1969 Apollo 11 mission?
item.description: It's 50 years since the first ever manned landing on the Moon - what was involved?

item.title: Predator Free 2050: New Zealand ramps up plan to purge all pests
item.description: New Zealand digs in with its controversial plan to protect native species by wiping out all predators.

item.title: Why blue jeans are going green
item.description: A growing number of denim producers are embracing environmentally-friendly production methods.

item.title: Remote Mount Michael volcano hosts persistent lava lake
item.description: The rare feature exists inside the crater of the Mount Michael stratovolcano in the South Atlantic.

item.title: The chart that defines our warming world
item.description: Communicating what's meant by climate change in one simple, easy to understand visualisation.

item.title: The nuclear fight for Sizewell on Suffolk's coast
item.description: The nuclear industry says new plants are essential, but protesters say the environment is under threat.

item.title: Why are Nike trainers washing up on beaches?
item.description: From Bermuda and the Azores to Ireland and France, large numbers of shoes are washing ashore.

item.title: Face to face with DR Congo's deadly vipers
item.description: Photographer Hugh Kinsella Cunningham captures close-up portraits of some of the world's most dangerous snakes.

item.title: Wreckfish: The fish that gobbles up unsuspecting sharks
item.description: These sharks thought it was swordfish on the menu, but there was something hungrier in the darkness.

item.title: Environmental work in Brecon Beacons estate handed to young people
item.description: The project will restore habitats and ecosystems and explore innovative farming and forestry approaches.

item.title: 'Climategate': 10 years on, what's changed?
item.description: Hackers stole 6,000 emails and other documents from a climate research centre almost 10 years ago.

item.title: How a fake hand test can help the study of empathy
item.description: People with a rare condition called mirror-touch synesthesia could help scientists understand empathy.

item.title: Igloo made out of empty plastic milk bottles at County Durham school
item.description: The structure aims to teach about plastic pollution and give the pupils somewhere to read and play.
